title: Major Works
subtitle: The Literary Legacy of José Rizal

content.title: Noli Me Tangere (1887)
content.subtitle: "Touch Me Not" - A Social Cancer

publication_details.funding: Rizal's personal savings plus loans from friends

cost_analysis.cost_per_book: Approximately 0.15 pesos per copy at printing cost
cost_analysis.actual_selling_price: Likely 1-2 pesos per copy for general public

content.comprehensive_summary: The novel exposes the abuses of Spanish colonial rule and the corruption of the Catholic Church in the Philippines through the story of Crisóstomo Ibarra, a young Filipino who returns from Europe with idealistic plans to reform his country through education. The narrative reveals the complex social dynamics of colonial society, the hypocrisy of religious authorities, and the suffering of the Filipino people under Spanish rule.

detailed_themes.description: Systematic exploitation of Filipinos by Spanish authorities
detailed_themes.examples: Kapitan Tiago's subservience, the guardia civil's brutality

detailed_themes.description: Criticism of friars who abuse their spiritual authority
detailed_themes.examples: Padre Dámaso's corruption, Padre Salví's lust

detailed_themes.description: Rigid class system separating Europeans, mestizos, and indios
detailed_themes.examples: María Clara's privileged position vs. Sisa's poverty

detailed_themes.description: Ibarra's school project as symbol of enlightenment
detailed_themes.examples: The proposed school in San Diego, Rizal's own educational philosophy

detailed_themes.description: Personal relationships tested by social and political pressures
detailed_themes.examples: Ibarra and María Clara's doomed love, Elías's sacrifice

major_characters.name: Crisóstomo Ibarra
major_characters.description: Young, wealthy, idealistic Filipino educated in Europe
major_characters.symbolism: Represents the ilustrado class and peaceful reform
major_characters.character_arc: From naive idealist to disillusioned revolutionary

major_characters.name: María Clara
major_characters.description: Beautiful, virtuous daughter of Kapitan Tiago
major_characters.symbolism: Represents the Philippines itself - pure but subjugated

major_characters.name: Padre Dámaso
major_characters.symbolism: Represents worst aspects of Spanish colonial clergy
major_characters.crimes: Falsely accused Ibarra's father, fathered María Clara

major_characters.name: Elías
major_characters.symbolism: Represents the oppressed masses and violent revolution
major_characters.background: Descendant of victims of false accusations

major_characters.name: Sisa
major_characters.description: Mother driven to madness by loss of her sons
major_characters.symbolism: Represents the suffering of the Filipino people
major_characters.fate: Dies calling for her lost children Basilio and Crispín

literary_significance.style: Realistic novel influenced by European literary movements
literary_significance.language: Written in Spanish to reach educated audience
literary_significance.influences: Inspired by Victor Hugo's Les Misérables and Harriet Beecher Stowe's Uncle Tom's Cabin
literary_significance.innovation: First novel to realistically portray Filipino colonial society

historical_impact.immediate: Banned by Spanish authorities, copies smuggled into Philippines
historical_impact.literary: Established tradition of protest literature in Philippines

content.title: El Filibusterismo (1891)
content.subtitle: "The Reign of Greed" - The Revolution

publication_details.first_edition: First edition copies in wooden boxes
publication_details.cost: 400 pesetas per copy (extremely high price due to rarity from Spanish confiscation)

cost_analysis.purchasing_power_1891: 400 pesetas = approximately 3-4 months' wages for average worker

modern_value_2025.normal_price_today: ₱20-25 in 1891 ≈ ₱30,000-50,000 PHP per book today (without confiscation)
modern_value_2025.comparison: El Filibusterismo cost 40-50x more than Noli Me Tangere due to rarity

cost_analysis.euro_conversion: 400 pesetas = 2.40 euros (1999 conversion rate: 166.386 pesetas = 1 euro)
cost_analysis.rarity_factor: Price inflated 10-20x normal book price due to Spanish confiscation
cost_analysis.normal_price_estimate: Without confiscation, likely would have sold for 20-40 pesetas per copy

publication_details.dedication: To the memory of the priests Gómez, Burgos, and Zamora

financial_struggles.payment_method: Printed on installment basis due to Rizal's limited funds
financial_struggles.initial_funding: Rizal pawned his jewels for down payment and early installments
financial_struggles.additional_support: Received money from Basa and ₱200 from Rodriguez Arias (from Morga's Sucesos sales)
financial_struggles.crisis: Printing suspended on August 6, 1891 due to lack of funds
financial_struggles.rescue: Valentin Ventura provided the necessary amount to complete publication
financial_struggles.post_publication_value: Rare first edition copies sold for as high as 400 pesetas each
financial_struggles.manuscript_value: Original manuscript later acquired by Bureau of Public Libraries for ₱10,000
financial_struggles.cost_saving: Foreword and Warning sections omitted from print to save costs

living_conditions.accommodation: Lived frugally in cheap boarding house with Jose Alejandro
living_conditions.economic_measures: Prepared own breakfast to save on living expenses
living_conditions.desperate_moment: Almost burned the manuscript in despair when funds ran out
living_conditions.gratitude: Gave original manuscript and autographed copy to Valentin Ventura

distribution.shipping: Copies shipped to Hong Kong in wooden boxes
distribution.confiscation: Most copies confiscated by Spanish authorities
distribution.immediate_recipients: Sent first 2 copies to Basa and Sixto Lopez in Hong Kong
distribution.rarity: Book became immediately rare due to widespread confiscation

content.comprehensive_summary: Set thirteen years after Noli Me Tangere, the novel follows the return of Crisóstomo Ibarra as Simoun, a wealthy jeweler who has adopted a revolutionary path. Disillusioned with peaceful reform, Simoun plots to incite a revolution by encouraging government corruption and abuse, believing that only through violence can the Philippines achieve freedom. The novel explores the moral complexities of revolution versus reform through interconnected stories of students, farmers, and colonial officials.

detailed_themes.description: Central conflict between violent uprising and peaceful change
detailed_themes.examples: Simoun's revolutionary plotting vs. Basilio's moderate approach, student activism vs. armed rebellion

detailed_themes.description: Systemic corruption in colonial government and society
detailed_themes.examples: Bribery in government positions, ecclesiastical abuse of power, Chinese merchant exploitation

detailed_themes.description: Quest for justice often becomes personal vendetta
detailed_themes.examples: Simoun's personal revenge against those who wronged him, Cabesang Tales' transformation from victim to bandit

detailed_themes.description: Student movements and the power of education to awaken consciousness
detailed_themes.examples: Spanish language academy proposal, student protests, Isagani's romantic nationalism

detailed_themes.description: Personal relationships tested by political commitments
detailed_themes.examples: Isagani's love for Paulita vs. his principles, Julí's sacrifice to save her grandfather

detailed_themes.description: Various forms of resistance against Spanish rule
detailed_themes.examples: Passive resistance by farmers, student activism, armed rebellion, intellectual opposition

major_characters.name: Simoun (Crisóstomo Ibarra)
major_characters.description: Wealthy jeweler plotting revolution, former idealistic reformer
major_characters.symbolism: Represents the disillusionment of the ilustrado class and the turn to violent revolution
major_characters.character_arc: From peaceful reformer to vengeful revolutionary to repentant dying man
major_characters.secret: Actually Crisóstomo Ibarra in disguise, seeks revenge on those who destroyed his life

major_characters.name: Basilio
major_characters.description: Orphaned child from Noli, now a medical student avoiding politics
major_characters.symbolism: Represents the younger generation choosing education over revolution
major_characters.background: Son of Sisa, witnessed his mother's madness and brother's death
major_characters.philosophy: Believes in gradual reform through professional achievement

major_characters.name: Isagani
major_characters.description: Passionate student activist advocating for Spanish language academy
major_characters.symbolism: Represents youthful idealism and romantic nationalism
major_characters.love_interest: Paulita Gómez, whom he loses to Juanito Peláez
major_characters.character_growth: From naive idealist to more realistic understanding of society

major_characters.name: Cabesang Tales
major_characters.description: Hardworking farmer whose land is stolen by friars, becomes outlaw
major_characters.symbolism: Represents the oppressed masses driven to violence by injustice
major_characters.tragedy: Loses everything to colonial greed, daughter sells herself to save him
major_characters.transformation: From peaceful farmer to revolutionary bandit leader

major_characters.name: Paulita Gómez
major_characters.description: Beautiful young woman torn between idealism and social ambition
major_characters.symbolism: Represents the Filipino elite's choice of comfort over principles
major_characters.decision: Chooses wealthy Juanito Peláez over idealistic Isagani
major_characters.significance: Embodies the conflict between love and social status

major_characters.name: Julí
major_characters.description: Cabesang Tales' daughter who sacrifices herself for family
major_characters.symbolism: Represents the innocent victims of colonial oppression
major_characters.sacrifice: Sells herself into servitude to raise money for father's ransom
major_characters.fate: Dies rather than submit to Father Camorra's advances

major_characters.name: Father Florentino
major_characters.symbolism: Shows possibility of moral authority within the Church
major_characters.role_in_ending: Counsels dying Simoun and disposes of his revolutionary treasures
major_characters.philosophy: Believes in God's will and gradual moral progress

literary_significance.style: Darker, more complex narrative than Noli Me Tangere
literary_significance.language: Written in Spanish with more sophisticated political discourse
literary_significance.influences: Reflects Rizal's growing pessimism about peaceful reform
literary_significance.innovation: First Filipino novel to seriously examine revolutionary ideology
literary_significance.narrative_technique: Multiple perspectives showing different responses to oppression

historical_impact.immediate: Also banned by Spanish authorities, considered more dangerous than Noli
historical_impact.political: Provided intellectual framework for Philippine Revolution of 1896
historical_impact.cultural: Deepened Filipino understanding of colonial psychology and resistance
historical_impact.literary: Influenced subsequent revolutionary and post-colonial literature
historical_impact.educational: Used to teach about moral complexities of resistance movements
historical_impact.international: Recognized as significant work of post-colonial literature globally

content.title: Annotations to Morga's "Sucesos de las Islas Filipinas" (1890)
content.description: Rizal republished Dr. Antonio de Morga's 1609 historical account with extensive annotations to demonstrate that the Philippines had an advanced civilization before Spanish colonization. Published in Paris in 1890, this work was crucial to the propaganda movement.

quote.text: In my 'NOLI ME TANGERE' I commenced to sketch the present conditions obtaining in our country... it is necessary to first lay bare the past, in order the better to judge the present and to survey the road trodden during three centuries.
quote.author: José Rizal

chapters.title: Pre-Colonial Civilization
chapters.content: Rizal corrects Morga's account by emphasizing that Filipinos had well-developed trade relations with China, Borneo, and other Asian countries. He notes their advanced metallurgy, including cannon foundries that produced artillery "as great as those of Malaga."

chapters.title: Government and Social Structure
chapters.content: Highlights the sophisticated political system with rajas and datus, noting that Manila's aristocracy lived in what is now Malate after being displaced by Spanish colonizers. Emphasizes the courteous and well-mannered nature of pre-colonial Filipinos.

chapters.title: Arts, Culture, and Literature
chapters.content: Rizal regrets the loss of ancient Filipino minstrels who memorized genealogies and heroic deeds in songs. He notes the women of Malate were "very expert in lace-making, so much so that they were not at all behind the women of Flanders."

chapters.title: Religious Beliefs and Practices
chapters.content: Challenges Morga's claim that all provinces welcomed conversion, noting that mountain tribes often resisted and required military escorts for missionaries. Emphasizes that forced conversion contradicted the peaceful nature of true Christian evangelization.

chapters.title: Economic Life and Trade
chapters.content: Describes the advanced economic system including sophisticated trade networks, skilled craftsmanship, and agricultural techniques. Rizal emphasizes that Spanish colonization disrupted rather than improved these existing economic structures.

chapters.title: Military Organization and Warfare
chapters.content: Points out that Filipinos had organized military forces and defensive strategies. Notes that Spanish accounts often exaggerated their own heroism while minimizing Filipino military capabilities and the organized resistance they encountered.

chapters.title: Cultural Prejudices and Stereotypes
chapters.content: Challenges Spanish prejudices about Filipino food, customs, and behavior. Uses the example of fish preferences to show how cultural misunderstanding led to unfair characterizations, arguing that "each is nauseated with what he is unaccustomed to."

chapters.title: Women and Social Morality
chapters.content: Defends Filipino women against Spanish slanders, arguing that the Philippines "has no reason to blush in comparing its womankind with the women of the most chaste nation in the world." Attributes any social problems to Spanish colonial influence.

right_column: International trade networks existed before Spain
Forced conversion was often violent and coercive
Filipino women and culture were highly developed
Historical truth must be recovered and preserved

content.historical_significance: This work provided intellectual ammunition for the propaganda movement by proving that the Philippines had a rich pre-colonial history. It countered Spanish claims that they brought civilization to a primitive land and became a foundation for Filipino nationalism and identity formation.

content.title: "The Indolence of the Filipino" (1890)
content.description: A comprehensive defense of the Filipino character against Spanish accusations of laziness. Rizal argues that centuries of oppression, not inherent laziness, caused the apparent indolence of Filipinos.
main_arguments: Lack of incentives for hard work

content.title: "The Philippines a Century Hence" (1889-1890)
content.description: A prophetic essay examining the future of the Philippines under continued Spanish rule, predicting either independence or absorption by another power.

content.title: "Mi Último Adiós" (My Last Farewell)
content.description: Written on the eve of his execution, this poem expresses his love for the Philippines and his willingness to die for his country's freedom.
content.excerpt:
Farewell, my adored Land, region of the sun caressed,
Pearl of the Orient seas, our Eden lost,
With gladness I give you my Life, sad and repressed;
And were it more brilliant, more fresh and at its best,
I would still give it to you for your welfare at most.

content.title: "To the Filipino Youth" (A la Juventud Filipina)
content.description: Written when Rizal was only 18, this poem won first prize in a literary contest and encouraged Filipino youth to be the hope of the nation.
content.excerpt:
Hold high the brow serene,
O youth, where now you stand;
Let the bright sheen
Of your grace be seen,
Hope of my fatherland!
